The monsoon had finally broken over Kolkata, leaving the streets slick with rain and the air thick with humidity that clung to everything like a second skin. DCI Ananya Parfitt stood at her office window on the fourth floor of Lalbazar Police Headquarters, watching the evening traffic crawl through puddles that reflected the neon signs of the city's countless shops and restaurants. Her reflection stared back at her—a woman in her early forties with intelligent dark eyes and prematurely grey streaks threading through her black hair, pulled back in a practical bun that had seen better days.

She'd been a solicitor once, back when she believed the law was something clean and orderly, something that made sense. That was before she'd seen too many cases dismissed on technicalities, too many victims left without justice while perpetrators walked free on procedural grounds. The transition to police work hadn't been easy—her colleagues still sometimes called her "Counselor" with varying degrees of respect and mockery—but at least now she could chase the truth instead of just arguing about it in stuffy courtrooms.

The phone on her desk buzzed insistently, dragging her attention away from the hypnotic dance of headlights below. "Parfitt here."

"Ma'am, we've got another one." The voice belonged to Sub-Inspector Rohan Chatterjee, her most reliable junior officer. There was an odd quality to his tone, a mixture of disgust and bewilderment that she'd grown accustomed to over the past three weeks.

"Where?" She was already reaching for her jacket, though the evening heat made the thought of additional layers unpleasant.

"Shyama Charan Mukherjee Nursing Home in Salt Lake. Same M.O. as the others."

Ananya closed her eyes briefly. That made seven now, seven elderly residents of various care facilities across the city who had been found in the same bizarre condition. Not dead, thankfully—though some of the victims seemed to wish they were—but traumatized in a way that defied easy explanation.

"I'll be there in twenty minutes," she said, already moving toward the door.

The nursing home was a modest three-story building tucked between a pharmacy and a sweet shop, its white walls stained with age and monsoon moisture. A small crowd had gathered outside despite the late hour, drawn by the flashing lights of the police vehicles and ambulance. Ananya pushed through the curious onlookers, flashing her credentials to the constable manning the entrance.

Inside, the familiar antiseptic smell mixed with something else—something that reminded her unpleasantly of a circus, all sawdust and strange chemical odors. She found Chatterjee in the common room on the second floor, speaking quietly with a woman in a nurse's uniform who looked like she'd seen a ghost.

"What do we have?" Ananya asked without preamble.

Chatterjee consulted his notebook, though she suspected he knew the details by heart already. "Mrs. Kamala Bose, seventy-three years old, been a resident here for two years. Her daughter found her about an hour ago when she came for her evening visit."

"Same condition as the others?"

"Exactly the same. Hair dyed bright purple—lilac, the nurse says—and she keeps claiming someone was tickling her. She's barely coherent, keeps laughing and crying at the same time. The medical staff don't know what to make of it."

Ananya had seen it before, unfortunately. The victims were always elderly, always found with their hair transformed into that distinctive shade of purple-pink, and always exhibiting signs of what the doctors could only describe as extreme overstimulation. They laughed uncontrollably one moment and sobbed the next, often simultaneously, their nervous systems apparently overwhelmed by whatever had been done to them.

"Any witnesses this time?"

"That's where it gets interesting." Chatterjee lowered his voice and gestured toward the corridor. "The security guard says he saw someone leaving through the back exit around the time Mrs. Bose was found. Big person, he says. Really big. Thought it might be a new orderly he hadn't met yet, but the supervisor says they haven't hired anyone new in months."

Ananya felt a familiar tingle of anticipation. In the previous six cases, they'd had no witnesses, no security footage, nothing but traumatized elderly people and the lingering smell of hair dye and something else they couldn't identify. "Did he get a good look?"

"Says the person was huge, maybe seven feet tall, but the lighting in that area is poor. He mainly noticed because of the size and because..." Chatterjee paused, looking uncomfortable.

"Because what?"

"Because of the laughter. He says he heard this deep, rumbling laughter coming from Mrs. Bose's room, but it wasn't her voice. Says it sounded almost... joyful. Like whoever was in there was having the time of their life."

The description sent an unpleasant chill down Ananya's spine. She'd read the statements from the other cases, and while details varied, several witnesses had mentioned hearing unusual laughter around the time of the incidents. Not the victims' laughter—that came later, the involuntary response that seemed to persist for hours after whatever was done to them—but something else entirely.

"I want to talk to Mrs. Bose," she said.

The victim had been moved to a private room where family members and medical staff could monitor her more closely. Ananya knocked gently and entered to find an elderly woman sitting up in bed, her daughter holding one of her hands while a doctor checked her vital signs. What had once been neat grey hair was now a shocking shade of lilac, professionally dyed but somehow garish against her weathered features.

Mrs. Bose was giggling softly to herself, but tears streamed down her cheeks at the same time. The effect was deeply unsettling.

"Mrs. Bose?" Ananya approached the bed slowly, showing her police identification. "I'm DCI Parfitt. I'm here to help you. Can you tell me what happened?"

The old woman's eyes focused on her with some difficulty. When she spoke, her voice was hoarse from what Ananya assumed had been hours of involuntary laughter. "So big," she whispered, then giggled again as if the memory amused her despite her obvious distress. "Green skin like... like a pickle. But the fingers... oh, the fingers were so clever."

"What did this person do to you?"

"Tickled me." Mrs. Bose's expression grew dreamy, almost euphoric, before shifting back to distress. "Wouldn't stop tickling. My feet, my sides, even my neck. I laughed until I thought I would die, but it felt... it felt wonderful and terrible at the same time. And all the while, she was laughing too. Such a deep laugh, like thunder, but happy thunder."

"She?" Ananya leaned forward slightly. This was new information.

"Oh yes, definitely a she. Kept talking while she worked on my hair. Said she'd always wanted pretty purple hair like mine, but hers never took the color right. Said she was jealous of all us old ladies with our nice white hair that dyes so beautifully." Mrs. Bose giggled again, but her tears flowed faster. "She seemed so sad about it, even while she was making me laugh."Ananya exchanged a glance with Chatterjee, who had been taking notes in the corner. The detail about the perpetrator's apparent sadness was something none of the other victims had mentioned, though to be fair, most of them had been in worse condition than Mrs. Bose, their recollections fragmented by whatever trauma they'd endured. The fact that this woman could provide coherent details, even between her fits of involuntary laughter and tears, suggested that perhaps the perpetrator was refining their technique—or becoming more careful about the amount of stimulation they inflicted.

"Did she say anything else?" Ananya asked gently. "Anything about why she was doing this, or where she came from?"

Mrs. Bose's daughter, a middle-aged woman who had been silent until now, suddenly spoke up. "Ma has been saying strange things since we found her. About gardens and flowers. Tell her, Ma."

The elderly woman nodded eagerly, her expression brightening despite the tears still tracking down her cheeks. "She smelled like jasmine and wet earth, like my grandmother's garden after the rains. Said she lived in a place with the most beautiful flowers, but they were all wilting because she couldn't take proper care of them with her funny-colored hair. She thought if she could make her hair pretty like ours, the flowers would grow better." Mrs. Bose paused to giggle at some private memory, then continued, "Such a silly thing to believe, but she seemed so earnest about it. Almost childlike, despite her size."

Ananya felt pieces of a puzzle beginning to form a shape, though she couldn't yet see the complete picture. The perpetrator was large, green-skinned, and apparently female. She had some kind of fixation on hair color and seemed to believe it affected her ability to tend to plants. Most importantly, she appeared to be operating under some kind of delusion that made her actions seem reasonable to her, even compassionate in a twisted way.

"Doctor," Ananya addressed the physician who had been monitoring Mrs. Bose throughout their conversation. "What's your assessment of her condition? Will the effects be permanent?"

The doctor, a tired-looking man in his fifties, shook his head slowly. "It's unlike anything I've seen in thirty years of practice. Her nervous system shows signs of overstimulation, but there's no evidence of drugs in her bloodstream. The hair dye is completely professional—better than most salon jobs, if I'm being honest. Physically, she should recover completely within a few days. Psychologically..." He shrugged helplessly. "The combination of extreme sensory overload and what appears to have been a genuinely pleasant interaction with her assailant has created a complex trauma response. She's simultaneously terrified and nostalgic about the experience."

This matched the pattern from the previous victims. All had recovered physically within a week, but the psychological effects lingered. Several had reported conflicted feelings about their attacker, describing her as frightening but somehow likeable, even motherly in a bizarre way. The nursing home staff had been baffled by victims who spoke fondly of someone who had clearly traumatized them.

Ananya thanked Mrs. Bose and her daughter, promising to do everything possible to find the person responsible, then stepped out into the corridor with Chatterjee. The strange circus smell was stronger here, and she found herself trying to identify the components. Hair bleach and dye, certainly, but also something organic and earthy, like greenhouse soil or compost.

"What are you thinking, ma'am?" Chatterjee asked as they walked toward the stairwell.

"I'm thinking we're dealing with someone who isn't entirely rational, but who has a consistent internal logic to her actions. She's not randomly targeting elderly people—she's specifically seeking out those with grey or white hair that will take dye well. And she genuinely seems to believe that changing her own appearance will somehow improve her ability to care for plants." Ananya paused at the top of the stairs, looking back toward Mrs. Bose's room. "The question is whether we're dealing with someone who's mentally ill, or someone who operates under a completely different set of rules than the rest of us."

"Different rules, ma'am?"

Ananya had been thinking about this possibility since the third incident, though she hadn't voiced it to anyone yet. The physical description—seven feet tall with green skin—combined with the strange beliefs about hair color affecting plant growth and the almost supernatural ability to enter secured facilities without being detected suggested something that didn't fit normal criminal profiles.

"Rohan, in all your years on the force, have you ever encountered a case where the perpetrator's physical description was consistent across multiple witnesses, but the description itself was... unusual?" She chose her words carefully, not wanting to sound like she was losing her grip on reality.

Chatterjee considered this as they descended to the ground floor. "You mean like the green skin? I've been wondering about that myself. Usually, witness descriptions vary wildly, especially when they're traumatized. But every single person who's seen our perpetrator mentions the same things—the height, the green coloration, the unusual strength. Either we have the most consistent group of witnesses in police history, or..."

"Or we're dealing with someone who actually looks exactly like they describe," Ananya finished. "Which raises questions I'm not sure I'm prepared to answer yet."

They emerged into the evening air, which felt almost cool compared to the stuffiness of the nursing home. The crowd outside had largely dispersed, leaving only a few curious shopkeepers and the usual collection of street children who appeared wherever police cars gathered. Ananya noticed that several of the children were pointing at the building and whispering among themselves in excited tones.

"Excuse me," she called to the nearest group, switching from English to Bengali. "Did any of you see anything unusual here tonight?"

The children looked at each other uncertainly until one of them, a girl of perhaps ten with enormous dark eyes, stepped forward. "We saw the big lady leaving," she said solemnly. "She was carrying a bag of hair things and crying."

"Crying?" This was new information.

"Yes, ma'am. Big tears rolling down her cheeks, but she was also laughing a little bit. Like she was happy and sad at the same time." The girl paused, then added with the matter-of-fact tone children used for the most extraordinary statements, "She gave us each a flower before she walked away. Mine smells like night-blooming jasmine, but it's not jasmine. I've never seen one like it before."

The girl produced a small white bloom from her pocket, and Ananya found herself staring at something that did indeed smell like jasmine but looked entirely unfamiliar. The petals had an almost luminescent quality in the streetlight, and the stem felt unnaturally sturdy for such a delicate-looking flower.

"Which way did she go?" Ananya asked, though she suspected the trail had long since gone cold.

"Toward the park," another child chimed in. "She was walking funny, like her feet hurt. And she kept talking to herself about purple hair and whether the roses would bloom better now."Ananya thanked the children and carefully placed the strange flower in an evidence bag, though she suspected the police laboratory would be as baffled by it as she was. The park the children had mentioned was Nicco Park, a sprawling recreational area about half a mile from the nursing home. If their perpetrator had indeed headed in that direction, she would have had access to acres of gardens, ponds, and wooded areas where she could easily disappear.

"We should canvass the park area," Chatterjee suggested, but his tone indicated he understood how futile the effort would likely be. "Though with the monsoon, any physical evidence will be long gone by now."

Ananya nodded absently, her mind still processing the children's account. The detail about the perpetrator crying while laughing echoed Mrs. Bose's own emotional state, suggesting some kind of psychological connection between the attacker and her victims. More intriguingly, the fact that she had given flowers to the children indicated a nurturing impulse that seemed at odds with her criminal behavior. She was beginning to form a profile of someone who was perhaps not malicious so much as profoundly confused about appropriate social interaction.

The drive back to Lalbazar gave Ananya time to consider the broader pattern emerging from the seven incidents. All had occurred at eldercare facilities, but the locations were scattered across different neighborhoods with no apparent connection between them. The perpetrator seemed to have intimate knowledge of each facility's layout and security measures, suggesting either extensive surveillance beforehand or an uncanny ability to navigate unfamiliar buildings. Most puzzling was the complete absence of forced entry at any of the locations—doors and windows remained secure, security systems showed no signs of tampering, yet somehow a seven-foot-tall individual with distinctive green skin managed to enter and exit without detection by cameras or electronic monitoring.

Back at headquarters, Ananya spread the case files across her desk and began looking for connections she might have missed. The victims ranged in age from sixty-eight to eighty-one, with no obvious relationships between them beyond their residence in care facilities and their hair color prior to the attacks. Three had been suffering from various stages of dementia, two had mobility issues, one was recovering from hip surgery, and Mrs. Bose had been in relatively good health for her age. The facilities themselves represented a cross-section of the city's eldercare options, from expensive private nursing homes to government-subsidized residential care centers.

What struck her most forcefully was the meticulous nature of the hair dyeing process. According to the medical reports, each victim's hair had been professionally bleached before the color was applied, a process that would have taken several hours to complete properly. This suggested that the perpetrator had spent significant time with each victim, yet none of them reported being restrained or prevented from calling for help. Instead, they described being continuously tickled throughout the process, apparently to the point where they were unable to do anything but laugh helplessly while their hair was being transformed.

The psychological profiles prepared by the department's consulting psychiatrist had been largely unhelpful, focusing on standard criminal motivations that didn't seem to apply to this case. There was no evidence of sexual assault, financial theft, or physical violence beyond the overstimulation caused by prolonged tickling. The perpetrator seemed genuinely concerned with the victims' comfort and wellbeing, even as she subjected them to hours of involuntary sensory overload. Dr. Mehta, the psychiatrist, had suggested they might be dealing with someone suffering from a rare form of dissociative disorder, but even that diagnosis felt inadequate to explain the consistency and bizarre specificity of the crimes.

Ananya's phone rang, interrupting her review of the medical reports. The caller ID showed the number for City Hospital's emergency department.

"DCI Parfitt? This is Dr. Sarah Khurana at City Hospital. We have a situation here that I think you need to see immediately. We've just admitted an elderly man with the same symptoms as those other nursing home cases, but this one is different."

"Different how?" Ananya was already reaching for her jacket again, despite the late hour and her exhaustion.

"He wasn't found at a care facility. His family discovered him in his own home, and he's in much worse condition than the previous victims. More importantly, he keeps asking for someone called the 'Garden Lady' and insists she's coming back to finish what she started. He seems to think she left something behind."

The drive to City Hospital took Ananya through streets that gleamed wetly under the sodium lights, the monsoon having left the city looking washed and somehow more vivid than usual. She found herself thinking about the strange flower the street child had given her, now sealed in an evidence bag in her briefcase. Something about its otherworldly appearance nagged at her, as if it represented a piece of the puzzle she was missing, a clue to understanding their perpetrator's true nature and motivations.

Dr. Khurana met her at the hospital entrance, a compact woman with graying hair and the kind of focused intensity that came from years of emergency medicine. She led Ananya through corridors that smelled of disinfectant and floor wax, past rooms filled with the usual collection of late-night medical emergencies that kept city hospitals busy around the clock.

"Mr. Dipak Ghosh, seventy-four years old, lives alone in a flat in Ballygunge," Dr. Khurana explained as they walked. "His son found him this evening when he came by for his weekly visit. Same purple hair, same psychological symptoms as the others, but he's been going in and out of consciousness since we admitted him. When he is lucid, he talks about the Garden Lady as if she's an old friend who's promised to return."

They stopped outside a room where Ananya could see an elderly man lying in bed, his newly purple hair stark against the white pillowcase. Unlike Mrs. Bose, who had been alert and relatively coherent despite her emotional distress, Mr. Ghosh appeared to be in genuine medical distress, his breathing shallow and his skin pale beneath the harsh fluorescent lighting.

"What's causing the difference in severity?" Ananya asked before they entered the room.

"That's what worries me," Dr. Khurana replied grimly. "Best we can tell, he was subjected to the same tickling ordeal as the others, but for a much longer period. His nervous system has essentially been overwhelmed to the point of partial shutdown. It's as if whoever did this to him became carried away and didn't stop when they should have. Either they lost control of themselves, or something interrupted the process before they could bring him down from the overstimulation safely."**Chapter 2**

The next morning brought no relief from the humidity, though the rain had stopped sometime before dawn. Ananya arrived at her office to find Chatterjee waiting with a cup of tea and a stack of overnight reports that did nothing to improve her mood. The forensics team had found no useful physical evidence at the Shyama Charan Mukherjee Nursing Home, the strange flower remained unidentified by the botanical experts at Calcutta University, and Mr. Ghosh had slipped into a deeper state of unconsciousness during the early hours of the morning. Dr. Khurana had called twice to update her on his condition, and neither conversation had been encouraging.

What troubled Ananya most was the escalation in severity. The first six victims had all recovered within days, their experiences traumatic but not life-threatening. Mrs. Bose was already showing signs of improvement, her involuntary laughter becoming less frequent and her lucid periods growing longer. But Mr. Ghosh represented a dangerous development in their perpetrator's pattern, suggesting either a loss of control or a deliberate increase in the intensity of her methods. Either possibility meant that future victims might not be as fortunate as the earlier ones had been.

Chatterjee had spent the morning coordinating with the various eldercare facilities across the city, implementing additional security measures and warning staff to be alert for any unusual activity. The response had been mixed—some administrators took the threat seriously and agreed to increase their night patrols and improve their access controls, while others seemed to view the whole situation as an elaborate hoax or media fabrication. The fact that none of the facilities had been able to explain how their security had been breached in the first place made their skepticism understandable, if frustrating.

"There's something else, ma'am," Chatterjee said as he settled into the chair across from her desk. "I've been going through missing persons reports for the past six months, looking for anyone matching our perpetrator's description. Obviously, a seven-foot-tall woman with green skin would be fairly memorable, so I wasn't expecting to find much. But I did find something interesting." He opened his notebook and consulted several pages of handwritten notes. "Three months ago, there was a report filed about someone stealing plants from the Botanical Gardens. Night security found several rare specimens missing from the greenhouse complex, along with professional gardening equipment and what they described as an 'unusual amount of potting soil and plant food.' The thief apparently knew exactly which plants to take—all of them were exotic flowering species that require very specific growing conditions."

Ananya felt the familiar tingle that came with a potential breakthrough. The connection between their perpetrator's apparent obsession with plant care and actual plant theft was too significant to ignore. "Did they have any security footage from the gardens?"

"That's where it gets interesting. The cameras malfunctioned that night—not damaged or tampered with, according to the technicians, just completely non-functional during a six-hour period. When they came back online, everything appeared normal except for the missing plants and some very large footprints in the greenhouse soil. The security staff assumed it was an equipment failure coinciding with an unusually well-informed theft, but now..." Chatterjee shrugged meaningfully.

"Now it fits the pattern of someone who can somehow avoid electronic detection while moving through secured areas," Ananya finished. She leaned back in her chair, considering the implications. "What kind of plants were stolen?"

"According to the botanical staff, they were all night-blooming varieties. Jasmine, moonflower, evening primrose, night-blooming cereus—plants that open their flowers after dark and are pollinated by nocturnal insects or bats. The head gardener said it was like someone had specifically selected every plant in their collection that blooms at night, regardless of their individual value or rarity." Chatterjee paused to flip through his notes again. "There's one more thing. The gardener mentioned that the thief seemed to understand exactly how to remove the plants without damaging their root systems. These weren't random acts of vandalism—whoever took them knew enough about horticulture to ensure the plants would survive transplantation."

The picture that was emerging of their perpetrator grew more complex with each new detail. She was clearly intelligent and knowledgeable about both hair care and gardening, suggesting either formal training or extensive self-education in both areas. Her ability to avoid security systems while moving through various facilities indicated either technological sophistication or capabilities that defied conventional explanation. Most importantly, her fixation on both hair color and night-blooming plants suggested a connection between the two obsessions that Ananya was only beginning to understand.

"I want to visit the Botanical Gardens," she said, already gathering her papers and reaching for her jacket. "If our Garden Lady has been using stolen plants to create some kind of private garden, she might have left other clues about her location or motivations."

The drive to the Botanical Gardens took them through some of the city's most congested areas, where the combination of monsoon flooding and ongoing construction projects had reduced traffic to a crawling pace. Ananya used the time to review what they knew about Mr. Ghosh's situation, hoping to find some clue that might explain why his experience had been so much more severe than the previous victims. According to his son, the elderly man had been in good health for his age, with no underlying conditions that might have made him more vulnerable to prolonged overstimulation. His flat had shown no signs of forced entry, and neighbors in the building reported hearing nothing unusual during the night when the attack presumably occurred.

What made Mr. Ghosh's case particularly puzzling was the evidence that his ordeal had lasted much longer than the others. The medical examination had revealed that his hair had been bleached, dyed, and then apparently bleached and re-dyed again, as if the perpetrator had been unsatisfied with her initial results and decided to start over. The process would have taken eight to ten hours to complete properly, meaning that the Garden Lady had spent almost an entire night with her victim, continuously tickling him while she worked on achieving the perfect shade of purple she seemed to desire.

Dr. Khurana had theorized that the extended duration had pushed Mr. Ghosh's nervous system beyond its ability to cope with the sensory overload. While the earlier victims had experienced intense but relatively brief periods of overstimulation, he had been subjected to hour after hour of continuous sensory input without any opportunity for his body to recover. The result was a kind of neurological exhaustion that left him unable to return to normal consciousness even after the stimulation ended.

The Botanical Gardens occupied several acres in the heart of the city, their entrance marked by ornate gates that had been installed during the British colonial period and maintained with varying degrees of success ever since. Ananya and Chatterjee were met by Dr. Rakesh Sinha, the head botanist, a elderly man with soil under his fingernails and the kind of deep tan that came from spending decades working outdoors. He led them through winding paths lined with labeled specimens, past ponds where lotus flowers floated serenely despite the urban chaos surrounding the gardens.

"The theft was quite sophisticated," Dr. Sinha explained as they walked toward the greenhouse complex. "Whoever did this understood not only which plants to take, but exactly how to extract them with minimal root damage and how much soil to take with each specimen to ensure successful transplantation. In forty years of botanical work, I've rarely seen such careful attention to proper plant handling techniques." He paused beside a large greenhouse whose glass panels reflected the cloudy sky. "More puzzling was what they left behind. Usually, thieves take the most valuable or rare specimens, but several of our prize orchids and exotic ferns were completely ignored. The selection criteria seemed to be based entirely on flowering patterns and fragrance rather than monetary value."

Inside the greenhouse, the air was thick with humidity and the rich scent of growing things. Empty spaces among the remaining plants showed where the stolen specimens had been carefully removed, leaving neat gaps like missing teeth in an otherwise full smile. Ananya knelt beside one of the vacant spots, noting the precision with which the surrounding soil had been disturbed and then smoothed over.

"Dr. Sinha, you mentioned that all the stolen plants were night-blooming varieties," she said, standing and brushing soil from her hands. "Is there any particular reason someone might want to collect only those specific types of plants?"

The botanist considered the question carefully, his eyes moving across the remaining specimens as if cataloging their various properties. "Night-blooming plants have certain characteristics that distinguish them from day-flowering species. They tend to have stronger fragrances, designed to attract pollinators in the absence of visual cues that work in daylight. Many of them also have more intense colors that show up better in moonlight or artificial illumination. Someone creating a specialized garden for nighttime viewing and enjoyment might specifically seek out such plants." He paused, then added thoughtfully, "There are also certain cultural and medicinal traditions that attribute special properties to flowers that bloom in darkness. Some believe they have enhanced healing powers or spiritual significance because they've absorbed moonlight rather than sunlight."

Ananya exchanged a glance with Chatterjee, both of them thinking about their perpetrator's apparent belief that her hair color affected her ability to care for plants. If the Garden Lady subscribed to some kind of folk belief system that connected lunar cycles, hair color, and plant growth, her actions might make sense within that framework even if they seemed irrational to everyone else.

"Is there anything else unusual about the theft that you haven't mentioned?" she asked. "Any other evidence left behind or strange circumstances surrounding the break-in?"

Dr. Sinha led them to a workbench near the back of the greenhouse, where several empty containers and gardening tools were neatly arranged. "The thief used our own equipment to transplant the stolen plants, but she cleaned and organized everything afterward. Most criminals would simply grab what they wanted and leave, but whoever did this took the time to wash the tools, return them to their proper places, and even sweep up the spilled soil. She also left payment." He opened a drawer and withdrew a small cloth bag. "Inside this, we found enough money to cover the cost of the stolen plants at retail nursery prices, along with a note apologizing for the theft and explaining that she needed the flowers for an important project."

The note was written in careful Bengali script on what appeared to be handmade paper. The handwriting was large and somewhat childlike, but the spelling and grammar were correct. Ananya read it aloud: "I am sorry to take your beautiful flowers without asking, but I need them very much for my garden. The people I want to help deserve to have pretty hair like these flowers, and I think having proper night flowers will help me do better work. I have left money and promise to take good care of everything. When my hair is the right color, maybe I can bring the flowers back to visit their home. Thank you for growing such lovely things."

The note confirmed several of Ananya's growing suspicions about their perpetrator. The Garden Lady genuinely believed she was helping her victims by dyeing their hair, viewing her actions as a service rather than a crime. Her reference to "proper night flowers" suggested some kind of connection in her mind between night-blooming plants and successful hair coloring, possibly related to timing her activities to coincide with nighttime or to some belief about lunar influences on hair dye. Most significantly, her promise to return the plants once her hair was "the right color" indicated that her current appearance was somehow unsatisfactory to her, despite the consistent witness descriptions of her green skin and purple hair.

"Dr. Sinha, have you noticed any other unusual plant thefts or disturbances in the city recently?" Chatterjee asked. "If our suspect is trying to maintain a large garden of stolen plants, she would need ongoing supplies of fertilizer, water, and possibly additional specimens."

The botanist nodded slowly, his expression growing more thoughtful. "Now that you mention it, several of my colleagues at other institutions have reported similar incidents over the past few months. Nothing as extensive as what happened here, but small thefts of specific plant varieties, always with payment left behind and always involving night-blooming species. There was also an unusual order placed with one of the commercial nurseries—someone requesting large quantities of specialized fertilizer designed for exotic flowering plants, along with professional-grade growing lights and climate control equipment." He paused, then added, "The nursery owner mentioned it because the customer paid in cash and had the supplies delivered to an address in the Sundarbans region. It struck him as odd because that area is mostly mangrove swamps and tiger preserve, not exactly suitable for the kind of delicate gardening operation the equipment suggested."

The Sundarbans. Ananya felt pieces of the puzzle clicking into place with almost audible precision. The vast mangrove forests south of Kolkata were largely uninhabited except for a few scattered fishing villages and research stations, offering the kind of isolation someone like the Garden Lady would need to maintain her activities without detection. The region was also known for its unusual ecosystem, where saltwater and freshwater mixed to create growing conditions unlike anywhere else in India. Someone with advanced knowledge of botany might be able to create a thriving garden there using artificial climate control and specialized care techniques.

More importantly, the Sundarbans were accessible by boat from dozens of points along the city's waterfront, providing a transportation method that would avoid the road checkpoints and security cameras that monitored most other routes in and out of Kolkata. A large individual traveling by water at night could move between the city and a hidden garden location without leaving the kind of trail that conventional police work was designed to detect.

"Dr. Sinha, do you know which specific area of the Sundarbans those supplies were delivered to?" Ananya asked, though she suspected getting precise location information would not be simple.

"The nursery owner might have records, but I seem to recall him mentioning it was somewhere near Canning. There are several research stations and eco-tourism facilities in that area, so it wouldn't necessarily have seemed suspicious to have gardening supplies delivered there." The botanist paused, studying Ananya's expression with the acute observational skills that came from years of scientific work. "May I ask why you're so interested in our plant thief? The amount of money and effort you're putting into this investigation seems disproportionate to a simple theft case."

Ananya considered how much to reveal, weighing the potential value of Dr. Sinha's expertise against the need to maintain operational security. The botanist had already proven helpful, and his knowledge of plants and growing techniques might be crucial to understanding their perpetrator's motivations and predicting her future actions. "We believe your plant thief may be connected to a series of more serious crimes in the city. Someone matching her description has been targeting elderly people in nursing homes, dyeing their hair purple and subjecting them to traumatic experiences. The connection between the stolen night-blooming plants and these hair-dyeing attacks suggests the same individual is responsible for both."

Dr. Sinha's eyes widened with surprise and concern. "That's... quite disturbing. Though it does explain some of the unusual aspects of the theft. If this person believes there's some connection between plant care and hair coloring, she might be operating under the influence of certain folk beliefs about lunar cycles and natural dyes." He was quiet for a moment, apparently processing this new information. The monsoon had finally broken over Kolkata, leaving the streets slick with rain and the air thick with humidity that clung to everything like a second skin. DCI Ananya Parfitt stood at her office window on the fourth floor of Lalbazar Police Headquarters, watching the evening traffic crawl through puddles that reflected the neon signs of the city's countless shops and restaurants. Her reflection stared back at her—a woman in her early forties with intelligent dark eyes and prematurely grey streaks threading through her black hair, pulled back in a practical bun that had seen better days.

She'd been a solicitor once, back when she believed the law was something clean and orderly, something that made sense. That was before she'd seen too many cases dismissed on technicalities, too many victims left without justice while perpetrators walked free on procedural grounds. The transition to police work hadn't been easy—her colleagues still sometimes called her "Counselor" with varying degrees of respect and mockery—but at least now she could chase the truth instead of just arguing about it in stuffy courtrooms.

The phone on her desk buzzed insistently, dragging her attention away from the hypnotic dance of headlights below. "Parfitt here."

"Ma'am, we've got another one." The voice belonged to Sub-Inspector Rohan Chatterjee, her most reliable junior officer. There was an odd quality to his tone, a mixture of disgust and bewilderment that she'd grown accustomed to over the past three weeks.

"Where?" She was already reaching for her jacket, though the evening heat made the thought of additional layers unpleasant.

"Shyama Charan Mukherjee Nursing Home in Salt Lake. Same M.O. as the others."

Ananya closed her eyes briefly. That made seven now, seven elderly residents of various care facilities across the city who had been found in the same bizarre condition. Not dead, thankfully—though some of the victims seemed to wish they were—but traumatized in a way that defied easy explanation.

"I'll be there in twenty minutes," she said, already moving toward the door.

The nursing home was a modest three-story building tucked between a pharmacy and a sweet shop, its white walls stained with age and monsoon moisture. A small crowd had gathered outside despite the late hour, drawn by the flashing lights of the police vehicles and ambulance. Ananya pushed through the curious onlookers, flashing her credentials to the constable manning the entrance.

Inside, the familiar antiseptic smell mixed with something else—something that reminded her unpleasantly of a circus, all sawdust and strange chemical odors. She found Chatterjee in the common room on the second floor, speaking quietly with a woman in a nurse's uniform who looked like she'd seen a ghost.

"What do we have?" Ananya asked without preamble.

Chatterjee consulted his notebook, though she suspected he knew the details by heart already. "Mrs. Kamala Bose, seventy-three years old, been a resident here for two years. Her daughter found her about an hour ago when she came for her evening visit."

"Same condition as the others?"

"Exactly the same. Hair dyed bright purple—lilac, the nurse says—and she keeps claiming someone was tickling her. She's barely coherent, keeps laughing and crying at the same time. The medical staff don't know what to make of it."

Ananya had seen it before, unfortunately. The victims were always elderly, always found with their hair transformed into that distinctive shade of purple-pink, and always exhibiting signs of what the doctors could only describe as extreme overstimulation. They laughed uncontrollably one moment and sobbed the next, often simultaneously, their nervous systems apparently overwhelmed by whatever had been done to them.

"Any witnesses this time?"

"That's where it gets interesting." Chatterjee lowered his voice and gestured toward the corridor. "The security guard says he saw someone leaving through the back exit around the time Mrs. Bose was found. Big person, he says. Really big. Thought it might be a new orderly he hadn't met yet, but the supervisor says they haven't hired anyone new in months."

Ananya felt a familiar tingle of anticipation. In the previous six cases, they'd had no witnesses, no security footage, nothing but traumatized elderly people and the lingering smell of hair dye and something else they couldn't identify. "Did he get a good look?"

"Says the person was huge, maybe seven feet tall, but the lighting in that area is poor. He mainly noticed because of the size and because..." Chatterjee paused, looking uncomfortable.

"Because what?"

"Because of the laughter. He says he heard this deep, rumbling laughter coming from Mrs. Bose's room, but it wasn't her voice. Says it sounded almost... joyful. Like whoever was in there was having the time of their life."

The description sent an unpleasant chill down Ananya's spine. She'd read the statements from the other cases, and while details varied, several witnesses had mentioned hearing unusual laughter around the time of the incidents. Not the victims' laughter—that came later, the involuntary response that seemed to persist for hours after whatever was done to them—but something else entirely.

"I want to talk to Mrs. Bose," she said.

The victim had been moved to a private room where family members and medical staff could monitor her more closely. Ananya knocked gently and entered to find an elderly woman sitting up in bed, her daughter holding one of her hands while a doctor checked her vital signs. What had once been neat grey hair was now a shocking shade of lilac, professionally dyed but somehow garish against her weathered features.

Mrs. Bose was giggling softly to herself, but tears streamed down her cheeks at the same time. The effect was deeply unsettling.

"Mrs. Bose?" Ananya approached the bed slowly, showing her police identification. "I'm DCI Parfitt. I'm here to help you. Can you tell me what happened?"

The old woman's eyes focused on her with some difficulty. When she spoke, her voice was hoarse from what Ananya assumed had been hours of involuntary laughter. "So big," she whispered, then giggled again as if the memory amused her despite her obvious distress. "Green skin like... like a pickle. But the fingers... oh, the fingers were so clever."

"What did this person do to you?"

"Tickled me." Mrs. Bose's expression grew dreamy, almost euphoric, before shifting back to distress. "Wouldn't stop tickling. My feet, my sides, even my neck. I laughed until I thought I would die, but it felt... it felt wonderful and terrible at the same time. And all the while, she was laughing too. Such a deep laugh, like thunder, but happy thunder."

"She?" Ananya leaned forward slightly. This was new information.

"Oh yes, definitely a she. Kept talking while she worked on my hair. Said she'd always wanted pretty purple hair like mine, but hers never took the color right. Said she was jealous of all us old ladies with our nice white hair that dyes so beautifully." Mrs. Bose giggled again, but her tears flowed faster. "She seemed so sad about it, even while she was making me laugh."

Ananya exchanged a glance with Chatterjee, who had been taking notes in the corner. The detail about the perpetrator's apparent sadness was something none of the other victims had mentioned, though to be fair, most of them had been in worse condition than Mrs. Bose, their recollections fragmented by whatever trauma they'd endured. The fact that this woman could provide coherent details, even between her fits of involuntary laughter and tears, suggested that perhaps the perpetrator was refining their technique—or becoming more careful about the amount of stimulation they inflicted.

"Did she say anything else?" Ananya asked gently. "Anything about why she was doing this, or where she came from?"

Mrs. Bose's daughter, a middle-aged woman who had been silent until now, suddenly spoke up. "Ma has been saying strange things since we found her. About gardens and flowers. Tell her, Ma."

The elderly woman nodded eagerly, her expression brightening despite the tears still tracking down her cheeks. "She smelled like jasmine and wet earth, like my grandmother's garden after the rains. Said she lived in a place with the most beautiful flowers, but they were all wilting because she couldn't take proper care of them with her funny-colored hair. She thought if she could make her hair pretty like ours, the flowers would grow better." Mrs. Bose paused to giggle at some private memory, then continued, "Such a silly thing to believe, but she seemed so earnest about it. Almost childlike, despite her size."

Ananya felt pieces of a puzzle beginning to form a shape, though she couldn't yet see the complete picture. The perpetrator was large, green-skinned, and apparently female. She had some kind of fixation on hair color and seemed to believe it affected her ability to tend to plants. Most importantly, she appeared to be operating under some kind of delusion that made her actions seem reasonable to her, even compassionate in a twisted way.

"Doctor," Ananya addressed the physician who had been monitoring Mrs. Bose throughout their conversation. "What's your assessment of her condition? Will the effects be permanent?"

The doctor, a tired-looking man in his fifties, shook his head slowly. "It's unlike anything I've seen in thirty years of practice. Her nervous system shows signs of overstimulation, but there's no evidence of drugs in her bloodstream. The hair dye is completely professional—better than most salon jobs, if I'm being honest. Physically, she should recover completely within a few days. Psychologically..." He shrugged helplessly. "The combination of extreme sensory overload and what appears to have been a genuinely pleasant interaction with her assailant has created a complex trauma response. She's simultaneously terrified and nostalgic about the experience."

This matched the pattern from the previous victims. All had recovered physically within a week, but the psychological effects lingered. Several had reported conflicted feelings about their attacker, describing her as frightening but somehow likeable, even motherly in a bizarre way. The nursing home staff had been baffled by victims who spoke fondly of someone who had clearly traumatized them.

Ananya thanked Mrs. Bose and her daughter, promising to do everything possible to find the person responsible, then stepped out into the corridor with Chatterjee. The strange circus smell was stronger here, and she found herself trying to identify the components. Hair bleach and dye, certainly, but also something organic and earthy, like greenhouse soil or compost.

"What are you thinking, ma'am?" Chatterjee asked as they walked toward the stairwell.

"I'm thinking we're dealing with someone who isn't entirely rational, but who has a consistent internal logic to her actions. She's not randomly targeting elderly people—she's specifically seeking out those with grey or white hair that will take dye well. And she genuinely seems to believe that changing her own appearance will somehow improve her ability to care for plants." Ananya paused at the top of the stairs, looking back toward Mrs. Bose's room. "The question is whether we're dealing with someone who's mentally ill, or someone who operates under a completely different set of rules than the rest of us."

"Different rules, ma'am?"

Ananya had been thinking about this possibility since the third incident, though she hadn't voiced it to anyone yet. The physical description—seven feet tall with green skin—combined with the strange beliefs about hair color affecting plant growth and the almost supernatural ability to enter secured facilities without being detected suggested something that didn't fit normal criminal profiles.

"Rohan, in all your years on the force, have you ever encountered a case where the perpetrator's physical description was consistent across multiple witnesses, but the description itself was... unusual?" She chose her words carefully, not wanting to sound like she was losing her grip on reality.

Chatterjee considered this as they descended to the ground floor. "You mean like the green skin? I've been wondering about that myself. Usually, witness descriptions vary wildly, especially when they're traumatized. But every single person who's seen our perpetrator mentions the same things—the height, the green coloration, the unusual strength. Either we have the most consistent group of witnesses in police history, or..."

"Or we're dealing with someone who actually looks exactly like they describe," Ananya finished. "Which raises questions I'm not sure I'm prepared to answer yet."

They emerged into the evening air, which felt almost cool compared to the stuffiness of the nursing home. The crowd outside had largely dispersed, leaving only a few curious shopkeepers and the usual collection of street children who appeared wherever police cars gathered. Ananya noticed that several of the children were pointing at the building and whispering among themselves in excited tones.

"Excuse me," she called to the nearest group, switching from English to Bengali. "Did any of you see anything unusual here tonight?"

The children looked at each other uncertainly until one of them, a girl of perhaps ten with enormous dark eyes, stepped forward. "We saw the big lady leaving," she said solemnly. "She was carrying a bag of hair things and crying."

"Crying?" This was new information.

"Yes, ma'am. Big tears rolling down her cheeks, but she was also laughing a little bit. Like she was happy and sad at the same time." The girl paused, then added with the matter-of-fact tone children used for the most extraordinary statements, "She gave us each a flower before she walked away. Mine smells like night-blooming jasmine, but it's not jasmine. I've never seen one like it before."

The girl produced a small white bloom from her pocket, and Ananya found herself staring at something that did indeed smell like jasmine but looked entirely unfamiliar. The petals had an almost luminescent quality in the streetlight, and the stem felt unnaturally sturdy for such a delicate-looking flower.

"Which way did she go?" Ananya asked, though she suspected the trail had long since gone cold.

"Toward the park," another child chimed in. "She was walking funny, like her feet hurt. And she kept talking to herself about purple hair and whether the roses would bloom better now."

Ananya thanked the children and carefully placed the strange flower in an evidence bag, though she suspected the police laboratory would be as baffled by it as she was. The park the children had mentioned was Nicco Park, a sprawling recreational area about half a mile from the nursing home. If their perpetrator had indeed headed in that direction, she would have had access to acres of gardens, ponds, and wooded areas where she could easily disappear.
